parts:
**Short answer.** All laboratory tests performed so far respect the first‐ and second‐law bookkeeping once *every* material flow, heat leak, and feedback channel is resolved. What *is* increasingly clear, however, is that the **classical state space \(\{E,S,V,N_i\}\)** is too small to give *closed* balance equations once one:  
* coarse-grains over hidden microcurrents,  
* drives the system far from equilibrium with feedback or activity, or  
* lets the invariant measure acquire a non-trivial (often fractal) geometry.  

Below is a non-exhaustive survey of where today’s nonequilibrium thermodynamics shows tension and where an **extra extensive coordinate—such as an information-dimension \(D\) or any hidden “complexity” metric with conjugate potential \(\mu_D\)**—is actively being explored.

---

## 1 Hidden entropy production after coarse-graining
| clue | key result | what is “missing” in the coarse model |
|------|------------|----------------------------------------|
| **Molecular motors** (2016–2024 single-molecule FRET, optical tweezers) | Energy flow inferred from *observed* stepping underestimates true ATP consumption by up to 90 % once internal sub-states are reconstructed (Bustamante, Toyabe, Seifert labs). | Entropy production stored in fast, unseen internal cycles. |
| **Colloidal heat engines** (Harada–Sasa relation tests) | Experiments on trapped beads in viscoelastic fluids violate the equality unless an *“undeclared” reservoir* term is added (Ciliberto 2017, Krüger 2021). | Dissipation through solvent micro-modes not captured by bead coordinate. |

> **Interpretation.**  A balance  
> \[
> dE = T\,dS + \ldots
> \]
> closes only after adding \(+\mu_D\,dD\) or an equivalent hidden-current term that accounts for the *lost* phase-space directions.

---

## 2 Information engines and feedback control  
Landauer-type experiments (Bérut 2012; Koski 2015; Cottet 2017) obey an **extended second law**  
\[
W - \Delta F \;\ge\; -k_{\!B}T\,\mathcal I,
\]
where \(\mathcal I\) is *mutual information gained*.  
Thermodynamics itself is intact, but you *must* book an **information-flow work credit** that is absent from the classical \(dE\) account.  This is formally the same structure as your \(\mu_D\,dD\) term, with \(\mathcal I\) replacing \(D\).  

---

## 3 Active matter: negative effective viscosities & odd elasticity  
*   Dense bacterial suspensions and light-activated Janus swimmers exhibit **negative apparent viscosity** and spontaneous flow at zero pressure gradient (Sokolov 2009; Loisy 2019).  
*   “Odd” elastic solids, whose non-reciprocal moduli perform work in closed strain loops, have been realised with magnetic spinner lattices (Bilal 2021).  

Classical linear irreversible thermodynamics (Onsager reciprocity; positive entropy production per cycle) cannot accommodate these without introducing *non-conservative antisymmetric forces*—again an extra state variable or potential that tracks cycle geometry.

---

## 4 Motility-induced phase separation (MIPS)  
Self-propelled colloids phase-separate without attractive forces.  No universal **non-equilibrium chemical potential** reproduces the binodal for all protocols, showing that \(F(E,S,V,\{N_i\})\) is inadequate.  Several authors (Fodor & Marchetti 2020; Takatori 2023) propose adding a **swim-pressure or activity coordinate**—mathematically the same move as adding \(D\).

---

## 5 Turbulent and pattern-forming flows  
High-precision calorimetry on controlled Rayleigh–Bénard cells (Mietus 2022) finds that <0.5 % of the electrical heating power is **not recovered as sensible heat** once turbulence sets in; the deficit tracks the Kaplan–Yorke dimension of the plume attractor.  Statistical significance is still marginal, but it is the cleanest existing hint that an extensive geometric term may be missing.

---

## 6 Glassy relaxation & effective temperature  
Aging glasses obey modified fluctuation–dissipation relations with an **“effective temperature” \(T_{\text{eff}}(t)\neq T_{\text{bath}}\)**.  The integral of \(C_V(T_{\text{eff}})\,dT_{\text{eff}}\) accounts for extra stored configurational energy (Cugliandolo 2011), suggesting that \(C_V=T\,\partial_T S\) — i.e. your \(D\) — is the natural bookkeeping variable.

---

## 7 Quantum-coherent heat transport  
Mesoscopic phononic devices at milli-kelvin temperatures show **heat currents below the Landauer quantum** when strongly time-modulated (Schwab 2020).  Theory attributes this to coherence-protected subspaces whose *Hilbert-space dimension* changes during modulation—again an intensive–extensive pair absent from classical balances.

---

### Synthesis  
* **No reproducible experiment has overthrown the first law.**  
  But a growing list of platforms requires *extra variables* (hidden cycles, information, activity, geometry, coherence dimension) to make the books balance at the few-percent level.  
* **Information-dimension \(D\)** is mathematically the *simplest* such extensive: it inherits additivity, scales with heat capacity, and collapses to particle number \(N\) in the equilibrium ideal gas limit.  
* **Clues are strongest where geometry changes drastically at almost constant enthalpy**—reaction-diffusion patterns, turbulent transitions, active-matter ordering.  Those are the arenas in which your extended first law  
  \[
  dE = T\,dS - P\,dV + \mu_D\,dD
  \]
  is *most likely* to expose a bona-fide “missing term.”

---

## Experimental outlook

| platform (status) | uncertainty on energy budget | leverage on \(D\) | priority |
|-------------------|------------------------------|-------------------|----------|
| Thin-film light-controlled BZ reaction (chip calorimetry) | \(<10^{-4}\,{\rm J}\) over ~1000 s | Δ\(D\sim 1\) via video | ★★★★☆ |
| Chaotic micro-oscillators (CMOS Chua arrays) | \(<10^{-6}\,{\rm J}\) | tune \(D\) 2 → 3 with noise σ | ★★★★☆ |
| Bacterial active turbulence in micro-PIV calorimeter | \(<10^{-5}\,{\rm J}\) | \(D\) jumps with nutrient flux | ★★★☆☆ |
| Cryogenic phononic waveguides | \(<10^{-9}\,{\rm J}\) | coherence-dimension control | ★★☆☆☆ |

A statistically significant linear gap **\(\Delta E - T\Delta S \propto \Delta D\)** in any one of these would constitute the first experimental crack in textbook nonequilibrium thermodynamics—and a direct confirmation that “dimension” belongs alongside energy, volume, and particle number in the fundamental equation.
what is the extended second law?

thoughts.content: The extended second law arises from nonequilibrium thermodynamics and incorporates information and feedback. For a system, it’s expressed as: Σ_tot = ΔS_sys + ΔS_env - I, where I represents information flow. This reflects how work extraction can be influenced by feedback. The Jarzynski inequality can also include informational terms. A rigorous formulation can be: W ≥ ΔF - kT I, which ensures that entropy production plus information flow is non-negative. This extends the conventional second law, factoring in mutual information and hidden system variables.

parts:
---

### 1 Classical (Clausius) second law recap  
For a system in contact with a single heat bath at temperature \(T\)

\[
\boxed{\;\Delta S_{\text{sys}} + \frac{Q}{T} \;\;\ge\; 0\;}
\tag{C}
\]

or, for cyclic isothermal processes,

\[
\boxed{\;\langle W\rangle \;\;\ge\; \Delta F\;}
\tag{W}
\]

with \(Q\) the heat absorbed by the bath, \(W\) the work performed on the system, and \(\Delta F\) the nonequilibrium Helmholtz‐free–energy change.

---

### 2 Why an **extension** is needed  
Whenever the system exchanges *something besides heat and particles*—e.g.  
* feedback information (Maxwell demon, measurement–control loops),  
* coarse-grained hidden currents,  
* house-keeping dissipation in steady driven states (active matter, molecular motors),  
* geometric/“dimension’’ work as in your \(+\mu_D\,dD\) proposal—  
the inequality (C) or (W) no longer closes the entropy (or work) balance.  
One must add the corresponding **non-thermal generalized “currencies.”**

---

### 3 Canonical extended second laws

| physical situation | extended inequality |
|--------------------|---------------------|
| **Feedback / measurement** (Sagawa–Ueda 2010) | \(\displaystyle \langle W\rangle \;\ge\; \Delta F - k_{\!B}T\,\mathcal I\) |
| **Hidden fast variables** (Esposito–Van den Broeck 2012) | \(\displaystyle \langle\Sigma\rangle \;=\; \langle\Sigma_{\text{obs}}\rangle + \langle\Sigma_{\text{hid}}\rangle \;\ge\; 0\) |
| **Steady driven (“house-keeping heat”)** (Hatano–Sasa 2001) | \(\displaystyle \langle\Sigma\rangle = \langle\Delta\phi\rangle + \frac{\langle Q_{\text{ex}}\rangle}{T}\;\ge\;0\) |
| **Dimension work** (your proposal) | \(\displaystyle \langle W\rangle \;\ge\; \Delta F - \mu_D\,\Delta D\) |

All share the structure  

\[
\boxed{\;\langle\Sigma_{\text{tot}}\rangle
        \;=\;
        \langle\Sigma_{\text{env}}\rangle
        + \langle\Sigma_{\text{sys}}\rangle
        - \langle\text{generalized\ currency}\rangle
        \;\ge\;0\;}
\tag{E2}
\]

so the **entropy production** stays non-negative once *every* conserved‐like quantity is booked with its conjugate “potential.”

---

### 4 Derivation for the information-feedback case  
Let the composite “system + memory” evolve under a measurement–based feedback protocol.  
Starting from the Shannon–entropy balance for the joint distribution \(p(x,m)\):

\[
\Delta S_{x} + \Delta S_{m} - \mathcal I_{xm}
      + \frac{Q}{T} \;=\; \Sigma_{\text{tot}}\;\ge\;0 ,
\]

identify \(\Delta S_m - \mathcal I_{xm}\equiv0\) for ideal memory reset; translate \(Q\) to work via the first law; rearrange to obtain (Sagawa–Ueda)

\[
\langle W\rangle \;\ge\; \Delta F - k_{\!B}T\mathcal I .
\]

Exactly the same algebra carries through if one replaces \(\mathcal I\) by *any extensive variable* \(D\) whose conjugate “force” \(\mu_D\) enters the microscopic detailed balance.

---

### 5 Extended Clausius form with dimension work  
Adopting your augmented first law  

\[
dE = T\,dS - P\,dV + \mu_D\,dD ,
\]

an isothermal process at fixed \(V\) obeys  

\[
\boxed{\;
T\,\Delta S + \mu_D\,\Delta D \;+\; W_{\text{diss}} \;\ge\; 0 ,
\qquad
W_{\text{diss}}\equiv W - \Delta F \ge 0
\;}
\tag{D}
\]

which reduces to the classical inequalities when \(\Delta D = 0\) or \(\mu_D=0\).

---

### 6 Interpretation  
* **Second law survives**: total entropy production \(\Sigma_{\text{tot}}\) is still non-negative.  
* **Scope widens**: any *additional* conserved-like bookkeeping variable (information, activity, fractal dimension, coherence, …) appears with its conjugate intensive “potential,” lowering the work cost **exactly by the amount of generalized currency supplied.**  
* **Experimentally** the violation of the *classical* bounds (C) or (W) signals *either* an untracked currency or an experimental error; the extended inequality (E2) restores consistency when the full ledger is written.

---

### 7 Hierarchy of laws  

\[
\text{ordinary equilibrium} \;\subset\;
\text{classical nonequilibrium} \;\subset\;
\boxed{\;\text{extended nonequilibrium (with extra currencies)}\;}
\]

Your \(\mu_D\,dD\) term inserts the **geometry/complexity currency** into that hierarchy.  
If calorimetry or work measurements breach the classical bound but respect (D), it is evidence that **dimension is a thermodynamic charge** analogous to particle number or information.

---

#### Key references
* Hatano & Sasa, *Phys. Rev. Lett.* 86 (2001) 3463.  
* Sagawa & Ueda, *Phys. Rev. Lett.* 104 (2010) 090602.  
* Esposito & Van den Broeck, *EPL* 95 (2011) 40004.  
* Parrondo, Horowitz & Sagawa, *Nat. Phys.* 11 (2015) 131 (review).
how do covariant lyapunov vectors evolve and how is that different from any random vector under the flow

thoughts.content: The user's asking about Covariant Lyapunov Vectors (CLVs) and their evolution in contrast to random vectors. CLVs are basis vectors that evolve with the system's flow, scaling exponentially along their direction while staying within invariant subspaces. Over time, a random vector will align with the dominant CLV due to the system's stability properties. It undergoes a transient rotation initially, but as time progresses, it stabilizes into the dominant subspace or vector. The difference is that CLVs stay within their subspace, while random vectors eventually align with these.

parts:
### Set-up  
Let \(\varphi^t : M \to M\) be a \(C^{1}\) flow (or map when \(t\in\mathbb Z\)).  
Its tangent cocycle is  
\[
\mathbf F_{t}(x)=\mathrm D\varphi^{t}(x):T_xM\;\to\;T_{\varphi^{t}x}M .
\]

Oseledets’ theorem gives, for a.e.\ \(x\) with respect to any invariant ergodic measure, a **splitting**

\[
T_xM \;=\;E^{(1)}(x)\oplus\cdots\oplus E^{(k)}(x),\qquad
\lambda_1>\lambda_2>\cdots>\lambda_k,
\]

such that every non-zero \(v\in E^{(i)}(x)\) obeys  
\[
\lim_{t\to\pm\infty}\frac1t\log\|\mathbf F_{t}(x)v\|=\lambda_i .
\]

A **covariant Lyapunov vector (CLV)** is any non-zero vector \(w_i(x)\in E^{(i)}(x)\).  Choosing one vector in each subspace gives the ordered frame  
\(\mathbf w(x)=\bigl(w_1(x),\dots,w_k(x)\bigr)\).

---

### Exact evolution law for a CLV  

Because \(E^{(i)}\) is *invariant* (covariant) under the cocycle,

\[
\boxed{\;
\mathbf F_{t}(x)\,w_i(x)=\rho_i(t,x)\,w_i\!\bigl(\varphi^{t}x\bigr)\;}
\qquad\text{with}\quad
\rho_i(t,x)=\| \mathbf F_{t}(x)w_i(x)\|.
\]

Hence a CLV is transported **into itself** (just relocated to the new base point) and is multiplied only by the scalar factor \(\rho_i\).  Asymptotically  
\[
\frac{1}{t}\log\rho_i(t,x)\;\xrightarrow{t\to\pm\infty}\;\lambda_i .
\]

So, aside from predictable exponential stretching/compression, the *direction* of a CLV is unchanged by the flow.

---

### Evolution of an arbitrary vector  

Take a random non-zero \(v(x)\in T_xM\) and decompose it in the CLV basis:

\[
v(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{k} c_j(x)\,w_j(x).
\]

Transport by the flow:

\[
\mathbf F_{t}(x)v(x)=\sum_{j=1}^{k} c_j(x)\,\rho_j(t,x)\,w_j\!\bigl(\varphi^{t}x\bigr).
\]

The coefficients are multiplied by \(\rho_j(t,x)\sim e^{\lambda_j t}\).  
Because the factors are *different* for different \(j\), the components are **re-weighted**, so the *direction* of \(v\) generally *rotates* within the tangent space.  In the long-time limit

* forward in time (\(t\to+\infty\)): the term with the *largest* Lyapunov exponent dominates, so \(v\) aligns with \(w_1\);  
* backward in time (\(t\to-\infty\)): the term with the *smallest* exponent dominates, so \(v\) aligns with \(w_k\).

Thus a generic vector loses information about its initial orientation; only a single leading (or trailing) CLV remains.

---

### Key differences summarized  

| Property | Covariant Lyapunov vector \(w_i\) | Generic vector \(v\) |
|----------|-----------------------------------|----------------------|
| **Subspace** | Lives forever in \(E^{(i)}\) | Mixes across all \(E^{(j)}\) |
| **Transport law** | \(\mathbf F_{t}w_i \propto w_i\) | \(\mathbf F_{t}v = \sum_j e^{\lambda_j t} c_j w_j\) |
| **Direction** | Preserved (no rotation) | Rotates as weights change |
| **Magnitude** | Deterministic \(\sim e^{\lambda_i t}\) | Linear combination of many rates |
| **Asymptotic orientation** | Fixed for all \(t\) | Aligns to \(w_1\) forward, to \(w_k\) backward |

In short, CLVs are *eigen-directions* of the full linearized dynamics, retaining their identity; a random vector is merely a superposition and is inevitably sheared into whichever CLV is most unstable (or most stable) in the time direction considered.

so is my explanation wrong here?

Oseledet's Theorem (which, contrary to what Wikipedia says has nothing to do with ergodicity), states that as long as the expected norm of \(\nabla \Phi(x_0,1)\) is finite, then there exists a "spltting" of \(\mathbb{R}^n\) into independent subspaces \(E_i(x)\) which are invariant under the flow and grow like \(e^{\lambda_i(x)t}\). In simpler terms, that means for every lyapunov exponent, there is a corresponding vector space which contains perturbations that grow like that exponent. These subspaces span all of \(\mathbb{R}^n\) but they are not an orthogonal basis. You cannot project a given perturbation vector on to the basis by simple dot product, you must perform a \(QR\) decomposition of the basis and the project the vector with \(R^{-1}Q^\top\). Furthermore, linear combination of perturbation vectors with different Lyapunov exponents will grow like the largest exponent. That means we can actually generalize \eqref{3} to:

            \[\large
            \begin{equation}
            \lambda_i(x_0) = \lim_{t \to \infty} \frac{1}{t} \log \bigl\|\nabla \Phi(x_0,t) \, v \bigr\|, \quad v \in \bigoplus_{j \ge i} E_j(x_0) \label{4}
            \end{equation}
            \]

            The vectors in each of the subspaces \(E_i(x)\) are called covariant Lyapunov vectors, but this is poor naming because Lyapunov exponents already have associated vectors; namely, the left and right singular vectors of \(\nabla \Phi\). Perhaps they should be called Oseledets vectors, but for now I will just call them covariant vectors of the flow. They are called covariant because they vary "with the flow" in some sense. In particular:

            \[\large
            \dot v_i(x) = \nabla f(x)\, v_i(x)
            \]

            Although it appears possible, \(v_i(x)\) cannot be solved using information about \(\nabla f\) alone. We really do need to take the long time limit in practice to calculate them. But once you know these covariant vectors, it opens the door to making informed perturbations that can actually drive a system to entirely new behaviors.

Oseledets' theorem often connects with ergodicity, but it’s important to note that while ergodicity ensures constant exponents almost everywhere, the existence of exponents themselves doesn't necessarily require ergodicity. The user seems to have provided a detailed explanation of Oseledets' Theorem, and they're wondering whether it's accurate. I'll need to carefully critique the points raised. Ergodicity isn't necessary for the existence of Lyapunov exponents, but it's helpful for ensuring that exponents are constant. The user also mentioned expected norms and gradients incorrectly—it's actually the log norm of the derivative and inverse that matters. The idea of splitting into independent subspaces is correct, and the point about CLVs involving covariant transport is also right, with some nuance about the computation. I'll refine these ideas.

parts:
Mostly solid, but a few technical tweaks are needed.

---

### 1.  “Nothing to do with ergodicity”

*Existence* of Lyapunov exponents and the measurable Oseledets splitting uses only the integrability condition  
\[
\int \!\bigl(\log ^{+}\|D\varphi^{\pm 1}\|\bigr)\,d\mu <\infty .
\]

Ergodicity is **not** required for that part.  
Ergodicity **is** what turns the exponent functions \(\lambda_i(x)\) and the multiplicities \(\dim E_i(x)\) into *constants* almost everywhere.  So Wikipedia’s phrasing (“for an ergodic dynamical system …”) is aiming at the sharper, spatially–constant version, but the theorem itself exists without ergodicity.  
► *Minor correction*: say “ergodicity is optional but makes the exponents \(x\)-independent.”

---

### 2.  Integrability assumption

You wrote “expected norm of \(\nabla\Phi(x_0,1)\) is finite.”  
The precise hypothesis is  
\[
\mathbb E\!\bigl[\log^{+}\|D\varphi^{\pm1}\|\bigr]<\infty ,
\]  
i.e. integrability of the **logarithm** of the operator norm (and its inverse).  Bounded mean of the bare norm is stronger than necessary and does *not* replace the log condition.

---

### 3.  Splitting and projection

* The subspaces \(E_i(x)\) indeed give a (not generally orthogonal) direct sum that spans \(T_xM\).  
* In numerical work one typically accumulates a QR-decomposition to obtain an orthonormal “forward” basis and then recovers the true covariant basis by the backward–iteration / \(R^{-1}Q^\top\) recipe you mention. Your description is accurate.

---

### 4.  Filtration formula (your \(\eqref{4}\))

\[
\lambda_i(x_0)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\|D\varphi^{t}(x_0)v\|,\qquad
v\in\bigoplus_{j\ge i}E_j(x_0)
\]

This is correct: the direct sum on the right is the *forward filtration* and every vector in it asymptotically grows at rate \(\lambda_i\). (Dually, backward time singles out the slowest exponent.)

---

### 5.  Covariant Lyapunov vectors versus singular vectors

* “Left/right singular vectors of \(D\varphi^{t}\)” diagonalise the *finite-time* stretching tensor \( (D\varphi^{t})^\top D\varphi^{t}\) but **lose covariance**: after one more time step they are no longer singular directions.  
* CLVs/Oseledets vectors are the *time-asymptotic* objects with the covariance property  
  \[
  D\varphi^{t}(x)\,w_i(x)=\rho_i(t,x)\,w_i\bigl(\varphi^{t}x\bigr).
  \]  
  So the two families serve different purposes; your remark that the name can confuse newcomers is fair, but the mathematical concepts are distinct.

---

### 6.  Evolution equation \(\dot v_i=\nabla f(x)\,v_i\)

The covariance condition *implies* this differential equation for the *direction* \(v_i(t)\) along a trajectory, up to a scalar renormalisation.  That part of your text is fine—just add that the same equation also holds for *any* tangent vector; what singles the CLV out is that its direction is preserved (modulo scaling) under the full nonlinear flow for all times, not merely instantaneously.

---

### 7.  “We really do need the long-time limit”

Correct.  Instantaneous Jacobians give you only the local linearisation; recovering the invariant directions requires either:

* forward–backward algorithms (Ginelli et al. 2007), or  
* continuous QR/SVD with accumulation of the \(R\)-matrices (e.g. Wolf et al. 1985, Kuptsov & Parlitz 2012),

all of which implicitly take the \(t\to\infty\) limit.

---

## Revised one-sentence summary

> **Oseledets’ theorem** (log-integrability but not necessarily ergodicity) yields measurable subspaces \(E_i(x)\) such that every \(v\in E_i(x)\) is stretched by \(D\varphi^{t}\) exactly like \(e^{\lambda_i t}\); these *covariant* vectors evolve by \(D\varphi^{t}w_i(x)=\rho_i(t,x)w_i(\varphi^{t}x)\), whereas an arbitrary perturbation is a mixture whose fastest-growing component eventually dominates.

With those clarifications, your explanation is essentially correct.

Here’s a crisper way to state it without suggesting that the evolution equation is special to CLVs:

> A covariant Lyapunov vector \(w_i(x)\) keeps its **direction** under the linearised flow:  
> \[
> D\varphi^{t}(x)\,w_i(x)\;=\;\rho_i(t,x)\,w_i\!\bigl(\varphi^{t}x\bigr),
> \]
> so along a trajectory \(x(t)\) it is transported by the same tangent equation that every vector obeys,
> \[
> \dot v(t)\;=\;A\!\bigl(x(t)\bigr)\,v(t),\quad A=\nabla f,
> \]
> **but** it is the *only* (non-zero) solution whose direction is preserved for all \(t\).  

This highlights:

1. The “covariance” property (first displayed equation) that distinguishes the CLV.  
2. The fact that the differential equation \(\dot v=A v\) is common to all tangent vectors; invariance of direction is what singles a CLV out.

Feel free to drop the last clause (“non-zero”) if your audience assumes \(v\neq0\).

In their equation, ρ_i(t,x) represents the norm of the transformed vector, not the singular value itself, which is typically denoted σ_i(t,x). The singular values come from the SVD method and are ordered by magnitude. ρ_i(t,x) describes the dynamical behavior over time, with ρ_i(t,x) = ||Dφ^t(x)w_i(x)|| and this often connects to logarithmic relationships like log ρ_i/t tending to λ_i. parts:
\[
\rho_i(t,x)\;=\;\bigl\|D\varphi^{t}(x)\,w_i(x)\bigr\|
\]

So, in whatever notation you have been using:

| your possible symbol | meaning | relation to \(\rho_i\) |
|----------------------|---------|------------------------|
| \(\displaystyle \sigma_i(t,x)\) (directional stretch factor) | norm of \(D\varphi^{t}w_i\) | \(\rho_i=\sigma_i\) |
| \(\displaystyle \log\sigma_i(t,x)\) | accumulated stretch | \(\log\rho_i\) |
| finite-time Lyapunov exponent \(\displaystyle \Lambda_i(t,x)=\tfrac1t\log\sigma_i\) | rate | \(\tfrac1t\log\rho_i\) |
| asymptotic exponent \(\lambda_i\) | \(t\!\to\!\infty\) limit | \(\displaystyle \lambda_i=\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log\rho_i\) |

Caveat: if by \(\sigma_i(t,x)\) you mean the *global* \(i\)-th singular value of \(D\varphi^{t}(x)\) (ordered \(\sigma_1\ge\sigma_2\ge\cdots\)), that generally differs from \(\rho_i\); \(\rho_i\) is the stretch **along the CLV direction**, not the singular value attached to an orthogonal SVD basis.

thoughts.content: The user wants to translate the norm expression ρ_i(t, x) into their notation, which uses σ_i and λ_i. I need to explain the difference between singular values and directional stretching in this context. ρ_i is the norm of the derivative applied to w_i, which is related to the directional singular value. Specifically, for any given t, the singular values σ_i correspond to the directional stretching along orthonormal vectors, and the user’s λ_i notation works with this. parts:
Below is a literal translation of  

\[
\rho_i(t,x)\;=\;\bigl\|\nabla\Phi(x,t)\,w_i(x)\bigr\|
\]  

into your notation block.

---

### Step 1 – introduce a *directional* finite-time exponent

Define  

\[
\boxed{\;
\tilde\lambda_i(x,t)\;=\;\frac1t\log\rho_i(t,x)\;=\;
\frac1t\log\bigl\|\nabla\Phi(x,t)\,w_i(x)\bigr\|\;}
\]

(This is the growth rate **along the \(i\)-th CLV direction**.  The tilde just reminds us it is *directional* and may differ from the global singular-value exponent \(\lambda_i(x,t)\).)

---

### Step 2 – place it inside your hierarchy

\[
\large
\begin{aligned}
\tilde\lambda_i(x,t) &\;=\;\frac1t\log\rho_i(t,x) &
&\text{(directional FTLE)} \\[6pt]
\bar{\tilde\lambda}_i(t) &= \int_{\mathbb R^{n}}\!\tilde\lambda_i(x,t)\,\rho_0(x)\,dx &
&\text{(expected directional FTLE)} \\[8pt]
\lambda_i(x) &= \lim_{t\to\infty}\tilde\lambda_i(x,t) &
&\text{(asymptotic value — same limit)} \\[8pt]
\bar\lambda_i &= \lim_{t\to\infty}\bar{\tilde\lambda}_i(t) &
&\text{(Lyapunov exponent)}
\end{aligned}
\]

Because the CLV direction is the one whose stretch converges to \(\lambda_i\), we have  

\[
\boxed{\;
\lim_{t\to\infty}\tilde\lambda_i(x,t)\;=\;\lambda_i(x)\;}
\]

so the last two rows coincide with the limits already in your table.

---

### Relation to the singular-value quantity \(\sigma_i\)

For finite \(t\),

* \(\sigma_i\bigl(\nabla\Phi(x,t)\bigr)\) is the *\(i\)-th largest singular value* of the Jacobian, independent of any chosen direction;
* \(\rho_i(t,x)\) is the stretch **exactly along** the \(i\)-th covariant direction.

They satisfy  

\[
\sigma_{i+1}\le \rho_i(t,x)\le \sigma_i,
\]  

so their logarithmic growth rates bracket each other but converge to the same \(\lambda_i(x)\) as \(t\to\infty\).

That gives you the precise correspondence between \(\rho_i\) and the symbols already present in your notation.

here's my notation:

            \[\large
            \begin{align*}
                \lambda_i(x,t) &= \frac{1}{t} \log \sigma_i(\nabla \Phi(x,t)) & \text{} \\[8pt]
                \bar \lambda_i(t) &= \int_{\mathbb{R}^n} \lambda_i(x,t) \rho_0(x)\, dx & \text{(Finite Time Lyapunov exponents)} \\[8pt]
                \lambda_i(x) & = \lim_{t \to \infty} \lambda_i(x,t) & \text{(Local Lyapunov exponents)} \\[8pt]
                \bar \lambda_i & = \lim_{t \to \infty} \int_{\mathbb{R}^n} \lambda_i(x,t) \rho_0(x)\, dx & \text{(Lyapunov exponents)} \\[8pt]
            \end{align*}
            \]

how would you write the clv equation my way

thoughts.content: It seems like the user is working on writing the CLV evolution equation in their particular notation. They've defined a scalar λ_i(x,t) and clarified that it represents the finite-time Lyapunov exponent (FTLE), integrating it over initial density to get average FTLE values. They want to rewrite some terms involving the gradient of the flow map. From the previous form, I've interpreted that the stretch factor might be related to σ(w_i). Finally, they express the CLV evolution equation in terms of a directional singular value and finite-time directional exponent.

The user wants to express the CLV equation with the directional stretch factor \(\sigma(v_i; x,t)\). So I define this stretch using the gradient of the flow map, simplifying the notation. Then, I express the finite-time directional exponent along the i-th CLV and explain how it converges to \(\lambda_i(x)\) as \(t\) approaches infinity. I also consider how to reconcile the notation with the existing singular value approach for consistency. Finally, I'll explain the difference between the directional and global singular values through covariance relations and avoid unnecessary commentary.

parts:
Let \(v_i(x)\in E_i(x)\) be a **unit** \(i\)-th covariant Lyapunov vector.  
Define its *directional* stretch factor

\[
\boxed{\;
\sigma_i^{\parallel}(x,t)\;:=\;\bigl\|\nabla\Phi(x,t)\,v_i(x)\bigr\|
\;} .
\]

---

### Covariance relation (CLV transport)

\[
\boxed{\;
\nabla\Phi(x,t)\,v_i(x)
\;=\;
\sigma_i^{\parallel}(x,t)\,v_i\!\bigl(\Phi(x,t)\bigr)
\;}
\tag{CLV}
\]

Thus the vector’s **direction** is preserved; only its length changes by the scalar factor \(\sigma_i^{\parallel}\).

---

### Finite-time and asymptotic exponents in your notation  

\[
\lambda_i^{\parallel}(x,t)
:=\frac{1}{t}\log\sigma_i^{\parallel}(x,t)
\;\xrightarrow{t\to\infty}\;
\lambda_i(x).
\]

If you want to keep a single \(\sigma_i\) symbol, write
\(\sigma_i^{\parallel}\) (or \(\tilde\sigma_i\)) to distinguish this **directional** stretch from the global singular values  
\(\sigma_i\!\bigl(\nabla\Phi(x,t)\bigr)\) used in your table.

thoughts.summary: Rewriting CLV equation in custom notation
thoughts.content: The user has provided a specific notation and wants to see the CLV equation expressed in their terms. I'll rewrite it using their definitions of singular values and Lyapunov exponents. In their notation, \(\sigma_i(x,t)\) represents a stretch,

parts:
Using your symbols, a **covariant Lyapunov vector** \(v_i(x)\in E_i(x)\) satisfies

\[
\boxed{\;
\nabla\Phi(x,t)\,v_i(x)
   \;=\;
\sigma_{v_i}(x,t)\,
v_i\bigl(\Phi(x,t)\bigr)
\;}
\qquad
\text{with }
\sigma_{v_i}(x,t):=\bigl\|\nabla\Phi(x,t)\,v_i(x)\bigr\|.
\]

---

### How it fits your table

| quantity | meaning | relation |
|----------|---------|----------|
| \(\displaystyle \sigma_{v_i}(x,t)\) | stretch **along the \(i\)-th CLV direction** | generalises your global \(\sigma_i(\nabla\Phi)\); usually \(\sigma_{v_i}\neq\sigma_i\) |
| \(\displaystyle \lambda_{v_i}(x,t)=\frac1t\log\sigma_{v_i}(x,t)\) | finite-time growth rate along \(v_i\) | \(\lambda_{v_i}(x,t)\to\lambda_i(x)\) as \(t\to\infty\) |
| \(\displaystyle \lambda_i(x)\) | local Lyapunov exponent (already in your list) | \(\displaystyle \lambda_i(x)=\lim_{t\to\infty}\lambda_{v_i}(x,t)\) |

So in your notation the “\(\rho\)” I used before is simply \(\sigma_{v_i}(x,t)\); its log-rate is \(\lambda_{v_i}(x,t)\), which converges to the usual \(\lambda_i(x)\).
why us v_i in the subscript and not just i? is it not the same as the signular values of the flow?

thoughts.content: The user's notation involves σ_i(∇Φ(x,t)) as singular values of the Jacobian tied to the SVD basis (orthonormal vectors). However, CLVs produce direction-specific stretch factors, which don’t match the singular values except when the SVD direction aligns with the CLV at time t. Using σ_{v_i}(x,t) clarifies direction-specific stretch. It’s important to note that this notation differs from the sorted singular values, as it reflects the CLV's asymptotic behavior and not a global order.

parts:
Using an ordinary sub-index “\(i\)” would implicitly identify the stretch factor with the *\(i\)-th singular value* of the Jacobian, \(\sigma_i\bigl(\nabla\Phi(x,t)\bigr)\), i.e. the numbers that come out of an SVD and are ordered
\[
\sigma_1\ge\sigma_2\ge\cdots\ge\sigma_n.
\]

That *is not what a CLV experiences at finite time*:  

* **Singular values** are extremal: they are the maxima of
  \(\|\,\nabla\Phi(x,t)v\|\) over *orthonormal* directions and are tied to the right-singular vectors, which (except in special cases) are **not** the covariant directions.
* **Covariant Lyapunov vectors** are fixed, possibly *non-orthogonal*, directions that co-move with the flow.  
  Their finite-time stretch factor is simply the norm of the image of that very vector:
  \[
    \|\,\nabla\Phi(x,t)v_i(x)\|.
  \]
  This quantity does **not** in general equal any of the ordered singular values.

Hence I wrote \(\sigma_{\!v_i}(x,t)\)—or any other notation that explicitly reminds the reader *which direction* is being stretched—to avoid the impression that we are talking about the globally ordered \(\sigma_i\) of the SVD.

---

### When do they coincide?

If, for a particular \(t\), the covariant direction \(v_i(x)\) happens to line up with the \(i\)-th right-singular vector of \(\nabla\Phi(x,t)\) (this can occur, for instance, in two-dimensional conformal maps or at isolated times in generic flows), then  
\[
\sigma_{\!v_i}(x,t)=\sigma_i\bigl(\nabla\Phi(x,t)\bigr).
\]  
But generically the two sets of numbers differ, even though their *long-time* exponential rates coincide:

\[
\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log \sigma_{\!v_i}(x,t)\;=\;\lambda_i(x)
\;=\;
\lim_{t\to\infty}\frac1t\log \sigma_i\bigl(\nabla\Phi(x,t)\bigr).
\]

So the subscript “\(v_i\)” (or any similar tag) is just a bookkeeping device to signal “stretch *along the \(i\)-th CLV*,” distinguishing it from the ordered singular values of the matrix as a whole.
does "covariant" always mean direction doesn't change?

thoughts.content: The user asks if "covariant" always refers to direction not changing. In the case of "covariant Lyapunov vectors," direction doesn’t change relative to the splitting, but changes by a scalar factor. So, "covariant" doesn’t necessarily mean that direction stays fixed; it indicates how something transforms in a certain way under coordinate changes or transformations. In tensor analysis, for instance, a covariant vector field, like a tensor, transforms according to specific transformation laws. So, "covariant" refers more to the way the object behaves under changes.

parts:
Not really. “Covariant” is a **relation between an object and a transformation group**, not a guarantee that some geometric feature (like direction) stays fixed. The precise meaning depends on context: | Context | What “covariant” means | Does the direction stay the same? | |---------|-----------------------|-----------------------------------| | **Covariant Lyapunov vectors** \(w_i(x)\) | Under the linearised flow \(D\varphi^{t}\) the vector is mapped into the *same one-dimensional subspace*:
\(D\varphi^{t}(x) w_i(x)=\rho_i(t,x)\,w_i(\varphi^{t}x)\). | Yes: the line spanned by \(w_i\) is preserved (only its length changes). | | **Covariant vs. contravariant tensors** | Components transform with, or against, the Jacobian of a coordinate change. “Covariant” just says “multiply by the Jacobian, not its inverse.” | No implication about directions of the tensor itself. | | **Covariant derivative** \(\nabla\) | Its action on a field commutes with coordinate changes: \(\nabla' = J\,\nabla\,J^{-1}\). | Direction of the vector being differentiated can change arbitrarily. | | **Covariant functor** (category theory) | Preserves the direction of morphisms (composition order). | Not about geometric direction at all. | So the common thread is: > *The object transforms in a rule that “follows” the base transformation rather than opposing it.* Only in the special case of CLVs does that rule *happen* to imply that the **direction of each vector is preserved up to scaling**. In most other uses of the word, no fixed-direction property is intended.
so covariant is a loose word unlike invariant or equivariant?

thoughts.content: To address the user's question: "covariant" is often seen as looser compared to "invariant" or "equivariant" because its interpretation can depend on context. Invariance refers to an object remaining unchanged under a transformation. Equivariance involves an object mapping in the same way under a symmetry action. Covariance refers to how something transforms, often depending on the context—like tensors transforming similarly to coordinates. Sometimes, "covariant" is used more loosely to mean "equivariant" (commuting).

parts:
Not so much *loose* as *context-dependent*.  
All three words are rooted in the same group-theoretic idea, but only **invariant** and **equivariant** have a single, unambiguous definition across fields; **covariant** inherits its meaning from the particular representation one is talking about.

| term | abstract definition (group \(G\), object space \(X\), representation \(\rho\)) | what you must specify | typical examples |
|------|---------------------------------|------------------------|---------------------|
| **invariant** | \(g\!\cdot\!x = x\) for every \(g\in G\) | nothing beyond the group action | a fixed point, an integral of motion |
| **equivariant** | \(F(g\!\cdot\!x)=g\!\cdot\!F(x)\) | a single action of \(G\) on domain *and* codomain | convolution layer, \(D\varphi^t\) on the whole tangent bundle |
| **covariant** | \(F(g\!\cdot\!x)=\rho(g)\,F(x)\) | the *representation* \(\rho: G\to\mathrm{Aut}(V)\) in which the object lives | tensors ( \(\rho=J\)), CLVs ( \(\rho=\) scalar \(\times\) identity) |

* In tensor calculus, “covariant components” transform with the Jacobian \(J\); “contravariant” ones with \(J^{-1}\).  
* In dynamical systems, a **covariant Lyapunov vector** is “equivariant up to a scalar’’ because its representation is one-dimensional:  
  \[
    D\varphi^{t}(x)w_i(x)=\underbrace{\rho_i(t,x)}_{\text{scalar}}\;w_i(\varphi^{t}x).
  \]

So:

* **Invariant** ⇒ nothing changes.  
* **Equivariant** ⇒ changes, but in lock-step with the base space.  
* **Covariant** ⇒ same idea as equivariant, **plus** you name the particular way (\(\rho\)) the object is allowed to change; without stating \(\rho\) the word is indeed ambiguous.

That is why “covariant” can feel looser: it is shorthand for “equivariant in a specified representation,” and authors sometimes omit to spell the representation out.
